<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken
<<<code>>>: public class TestStringTokenStrict {
```java
/**
 * Strict implementation of StringTokenizer
 * 
 * @param str
 * @param delim
 * @param strict
 *            true = include NULL Token
 * @return
 */
static StringTokenizer getStringTokenizerStrict(String str, String delim, boolean strict) {
    StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(str, delim, strict);
    StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer();

    while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
        String s = st.nextToken();
        if (s.equals(delim)) {
            sb.append(" ").append(delim);
        } else {
            sb.append(s).append(delim);
            if (st.hasMoreTokens())
                st.nextToken();
        }
    }
    return (new StringTokenizer(sb.toString(), delim));
}

static void altStringTokenizer(StringTokenizer st) {
    while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
        String type = st.nextToken();
        String one = st.nextToken();
        String two = st.nextToken();
        String three = st.nextToken();
        String four = st.nextToken();
        String five = st.nextToken();

        System.out.println(
                "[" + type + "] [" + one + "] [" + two + "] [" + three + "] [" + four + "] [" + five + "]");
    }
}

public static void main(String[] args) {
    String input = "Record|One||Three||Five";
    altStringTokenizer(getStringTokenizerStrict(input, "|", true));
}
```
}

<<<explanation>>>: To properly end the file scanner while loop, you can use the `hasNext()` method instead of `next()` to check if there are more tokens to read. This will prevent the `NoSuchElementException` from being thrown when the end of the file is reached. Here's an example of how to modify the `dataRead()` function to use `hasNext()`:
```java
public static ArrayList<String> dataRead() throws FileNotFoundException {
    //ArrayList array = new ArrayList<ArrayList<String>>();
    Scanner s = new Scanner(new File("c:\\stats.txt")).useDelimiter("\r");
    ArrayList<String> array = new ArrayList<String>();
    int i = 0;
    while (s.hasNext()) {
        String currentLine = s.next();
        Scanner split = new Scanner(currentLine).useDelimiter("\t");
        while (split.hasNext()) {
            String one = split.next();
            System.out.print(one + " ");
            i++;
            if (i == 16) {
                System.out.println("\r");
                i = 0;
            }
        }
        s.close();
    }
    s.close();
    return array;
}
```
This modified version of the `dataRead()` function uses a while loop with `hasNext()` to read the file line by line, and then uses another while loop with `hasNext()` to read the tab-delimited fields within each line. The loop limit is set to 16 to match the number of fields in each line, but this can be adjusted as needed. The loop counter `i` is used to keep track of the number of fields read, and is reset to 0 when the end of a line is reached. This ensures that the loop will terminate correctly when the end of the file is reached.
